item.title: Trump Organization Is Said to Be in Talks on a Saudi Government Real Estate Deal
item.description: The chief executive of a Saudi firm says a Trump-branded project is “just a matter of time.” The Trump Organization’s major foreign partner is also signaling new Saudi deals.

item.title: What’s More Dangerous than India’s Frequent Heat Waves? Heat Stress.
item.description: Women who face long-term heat exposure in workplaces and homes are finding it takes a heavy toll on their health and income.

item.title: How Many People Die in India From Hot Weather? Nobody Really Knows.
item.description: Officials have yet to grasp the magnitude of heat-related deaths, let alone effectively deal with the problem, public health experts and scientists say.

item.title: Family of Fisherman Killed in U.S. Military Strike Says It Wants Justice
item.description: Colombia was a top U.S. ally in Latin America until the Trump administration began deadly strikes in international waters. Now, one family wants justice.

item.title: Protesters Rage Against Mexico’s Government Over Corruption and Violence
item.description: Members of Mexico’s Gen Z, as well as older protesters, demonstrated on Saturday in the wake of a high-profile assassination and rising anger over persistent violence.

item.title: A Challenge to Canada’s Official Policy That the U.S. Is Safe for Migrants
item.description: A former Liberal immigration minister said that Canada should drop an agreement that allows it to return asylum seekers who enter from the U.S.

item.title: Vatican to Return Indigenous Cultural Items to Canada Taken a Century Ago
item.description: Dozen of pieces used in a 1925 exhibition, including a whale-hunting kayak, will be returned to Canada early next month.

item.title: Displaced Gazans Face More Misery as Torrential Rain Lashes Enclave
item.description: Heavy rainfall and chilling winds have added to the challenges facing people still forced to live in tents in the devastated territory.

item.title: Pope Leo Urges Cinema Notables to Redouble Focus on Social Justice
item.description: But left unspoken at a Vatican meeting with film stars were the deep divisions over issues like abortion and homosexuality.

item.title: Russia Tried to Cut Ukraine’s Lights. Now It’s Aiming for the Heat.
item.description: Moscow’s attacks on gas supplies, the main source of warmth for most Ukrainian households, could plunge millions into the cold.

item.title: Tuning In
item.description: Sometimes we assume the people and things around us are neutral or hostile to our existence. What if the opposite could be true?

item.title: Fears Fuel Tanker Was Seized by Iran in Strait of Hormuz
item.description: The ship, which was flying a Marshall Islands flag, was passing through the Strait of Hormuz when it lost contact with its managers.

item.title: On a Clipped Wing, Flamingo Escapes a British Zoo for a Life in France
item.description: Frankie, a young Caribbean Flamingo, flew 130 miles from captivity. Her keepers said they would likely have to leave her in France.

item.title: 9 Dead After Accidental Blast at Police Station in Kashmir
item.description: The explosion in the city of Srinagar happened as Indian officials were inspecting bomb-making material seized in an investigation into a terror network allegedly involving doctors.

item.title: Seven Days of Paralysis: Inside the BBC Crisis Over a Trump Documentary
item.description: With board members and executives deadlocked over how to respond, the news organization kept silent for days, allowing a controversy to snowball.

item.title: Dar Global Is the Trump Organization’s Key Foreign Partner
item.description: Dar Global bet big on the Trump name. It is now an essential foreign partner for the Trump Organization.

item.title: What Happened to Gabriel Boric’s Leftist Promises for Chile?
item.description: When he was elected four years ago, President Gabriel Boric of Chile carried ambitious promises and new energy. Then reality kicked in.

item.title: How Trump’s Redlines Have Upended the G20 Summit in South Africa
item.description: At the annual meeting of the world’s major economic powers, U.S. objections are blocking the usual policy statements, highlighting the president’s distaste for multilateralism — and compromise.

item.title: Modi’s Coalition Sweeps Indian State Election Criticized Over Voter Rolls
item.description: The coalition was on course to form a government in Bihar, a state of 130 million people, where the opposition had claimed foul play over deletions from voter lists.

item.title: While Asian Immigrants Work, Burglars Target Their Homes
item.description: Some law enforcement officials say they think organized crime rings from South America, in particular from Colombia, are responsible for the crime sprees.

item.title: As Trump Targets Antifa in U.S., Rubio Labels European Groups as Terrorists
item.description: The State Department’s search for leftist groups to designate as terrorist organizations appears rooted in President Trump’s executive order on domestic groups that he calls antifa.

item.title: At U.N. Security Council, Russia Counters Trump Gaza Plan With Its Own
item.description: The Trump administration wants the Security Council to adopt a resolution that has the 20-point U.S. plan annexed, effectively making it international law.

item.title: Indigenous People Take the Stage at COP30 Climate Talks in Belém, Brazil
item.description: This summit is unlike any of its predecessors in at least one significant way: The Indigenous presence is palpable and strong.

item.title: Justice Dept. Memo Blessing Boat Strikes Is Said to Rely on Trump’s Claims About Cartels
item.description: Accounts of a secret Justice Department memo offer a window into how administration lawyers approved the president’s desired course of action.

item.title: Mexico City Loves Street Food. Its Sewer System Does Not.
item.description: The worst rainy season in decades caused flooding around much of the city. Fat from its many taco shops, restaurants and markets was a major reason for blocked drains, officials say.

item.title: Israeli Settler Attack During West Bank Olive Harvest Leads to Death of a Boy
item.description: Palestinians see the violence, and its tolerance by right-wing Israeli officialdom, as part of a broader campaign to harass them and make life so unbearable that they will abandon their villages.

item.title: Trump Plan Could Limit Green Cards for Immigrants From Travel Ban Countries
item.description: The policy change is a major expansion of the administration’s push to crack down on immigration from countries that it says lack sufficient screening and vetting abilities.

item.title: Zelensky Ousted a Heavyweight Mayor. Was It a Power Grab?
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky removed Odesa’s mayor, raising fears he might be using his wartime powers to tighten control over opposition-run cities.

item.title: Atrocities in Sudan Require World’s Attention, U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations’ top human rights body ordered an inquiry into mass killings and sexual violence during the country’s worsening civil war.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Said to Be Planning to Meet With Senior Hamas Official
item.description: An in-person encounter between Steve Witkoff and Khalil al-Hayya would signal the Trump administration’s interest in keeping a direct line of communication with the group.

item.title: Russia Pummels Kyiv and Tries to Plunge Ukraine Into Darkness
item.description: A strike that killed six was the latest in a series of aerial assaults, many of which have targeted the power grid in an effort to deprive Ukrainians of energy as winter looms.

item.title: Zelensky’s Image Is Stained as Corruption Inquiry Shakes His Inner Circle
item.description: The revelations are a remarkable reversal for the Ukrainian president, who once presented himself as a leader who would clean up the country’s politics.

item.title: Napoleon’s Brooch, Lost as He Fled Waterloo, Sells for $4.4 Million
item.description: The diamond-encrusted jewel, which the 19th-century French emperor wore on his hat, was lost along with other valuables as he retreated from his final battle.

item.title: Rapist Called One of UK’s Worst Sex Offenders Is Sentenced to Life
item.description: Xu Chao admitted to multiple attacks against female Chinese students over a three-year period, confessing to drugging, assaulting and filming his victims.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa Leaves Behind a Staggering Homelessness Toll in Jamaica
item.description: Two weeks after Hurricane Melissa wrecked western Jamaica, officials are beginning to grapple with the challenge of trying to find housing for thousands of families.

item.title: Kenya’s Key Export Used to Be Coffee. Now It’s Cheap Labor.
item.description: There’s big money in sending poor workers abroad. Here’s how the economics work.

item.title: Kenyan Workers Get Abused Abroad. The President’s Family and Allies Profit.
item.description: President William Ruto’s government acts as an arm of an industry whose leaders compare women to dogs and blame them for their own abuse, a Times investigation found.

item.title: Of Books and Men
item.description: My colleague, the book critic Dwight Garner, tells us about “Flesh” by David Szalay, this year’s Booker Prize winner.

item.title: A.I. Cheating Rattles Top Universities in South Korea
item.description: As many elite colleges struggle to adapt to the technology, the nation’s most prestigious universities said dozens of students used artificial intelligence tools to cheat.

item.title: Trump Administration Revokes Biden Ban on Drilling and Mining in Alaska Wilderness
item.description: The decision to allow oil and gas drilling in Alaska’s ecologically sensitive North Slope has the support of the state’s governor and senators.

item.title: What the U.S. Absence at COP30 Tells Us
item.description: World leaders are meeting at the COP30 this week to discuss climate. The U.S. was not part of this meeting. Somini Sengupta, our international climate reporter, discusses what this absence means.

item.title: Carney Accelerates Economic Plan for Canada to Rely Less on U.S. Amid Trade War
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney fast-tracked mines and other natural resource projects to the dismay of some Indigenous groups and many environmentalists.

item.title: BBC Apologizes to Trump Over Film Edit but Declines to Pay Compensation
item.description: The BBC said it would not rebroadcast a misleadingly edited documentary but added, “We strongly disagree there is a basis for a defamation claim.”

item.title: How France Remembers the November 2015 Terrorist Attacks in Paris
item.description: A decade ago, Islamic State militants killed 130 people in an assault that shocked France. Some survivors are still struggling, but for many of their compatriots, memories of the attacks are growing more distant.

item.title: U.S. Officials Raise Concerns About Saudi Arabia’s Bid for F-35 Jets
item.description: A Pentagon intelligence report says China could try to acquire advanced F-35 technology in Saudi Arabia if the Trump administration sells jets to the kingdom.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew and Another Prominent Briton Come Up in the Epstein Emails
item.description: Newly released files from Jeffrey Epstein include correspondence with Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor and Peter Mandelson, the former British ambassador to Washington.

item.title: The Global Climate Leadership Vacuum
item.description: The United States is largely absent from the United Nations climate negations in Brazil. So who is stepping up?

item.title: Ukraine’s Dilemma as Pokrovsk Teeters: Save Lives or Keep Holding On
item.description: Military analysts and some Ukrainian commanders worry that Kyiv may be repeating the mistake of staying in an embattled city longer than it should, aiming to inflict far more casualties than it suffers.

item.title: In the Faroe Islands’ Soccer Team, the Players Also Have Day Jobs
item.description: The Faroe Islands, rugged green specks in the North Atlantic, are an underdog. Most of the guys on the team have day jobs.

item.title: Israeli Settlers Burn West Bank Mosque Amid Rise in Violent Attacks
item.description: Since the 2023 attack on Israel by Hamas, growing settler violence and Israeli attacks on Palestinian militants have thrown the West Bank into turmoil and displaced tens of thousands.

item.title: What Our Photographer Saw as a Safe City Became a Blood Bath
item.description: The Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk is on the verge of becoming another shattered trophy for the Russian Army.

item.title: An Ontario Man Took a Bus for a Joyride. Turns Out, He’s Not a Bad Driver.
item.description: The incident in Hamilton, Ontario, ended safely with an arrest and no injuries (and all fares paid).

item.title: Bird Flu Ravaged the World’s Largest Elephant Seal Population, Study Finds
item.description: After the H5N1 virus hit the remote island of South Georgia in 2023, more than 50,000 breeding females may have disappeared.

item.title: Juan Ponce Enrile, a Political Power in the Philippines, Dies at 101
item.description: A protégé of Ferdinand Marcos, he helped administer martial law for eight years before turning on his patron in the “People Power” uprising of 1986.

item.title: Man Accused of Running Southeast Asia Scam Compound Is Extradited to China
item.description: China and the United States say She Zhijiang, a Chinese-born businessman, ran a major scam compound in Myanmar. He was arrested in Bangkok in 2022.

item.title: China’s ‘Wolf Warrior’ Diplomacy Returns With Threat Against Japan’s Leader
item.description: A Chinese diplomat’s call to cut off the prime minister’s “filthy head” signaled a revival of a combative style Beijing had tried to dial back.

item.title: How Pakistan’s Spending Blitz Helped Win Over Trump and Flip U.S. Policy
item.description: As Pakistan has hired lobbyists with close ties to President Trump, it has also received favorable tariff treatment and unique access in Washington.

item.title: Fake Bomb Threats Baffle the Police Across Asia
item.description: The threatening emails and faxes bear the signature of a man who says he is being impersonated. The police in five nations have failed to stem them.

item.title: He Helped Cities Anticipate Damage From Storms
item.description: Austin Becker developed an early warning system to protect critical infrastructure from storms. His project’s funding was eliminated in April.

item.title: Rubio Shrugs Off Allies’ Concerns Over U.S. Drug Strikes
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said no one raised the Caribbean military operation in closed-door meetings at a G7 summit. But ministers from France and the European Union publicly called them unlawful.
